text: Coming up next is the Science Fiction Radio Show, so stay with us. This is the Science Fiction Radio Show, a commentary on science fiction and fantasy. And here are your hosts. This is Bill Vernon and Daryl Lane. Jo Clayton is a science fiction and fantasy writer who is a discovery of Donald A. Walheim, publisher of Dahl Books. Other recent Walheim discoveries are C.J. Sherry and Tanith Lee. Clayton has published seven novels in the Diadem series and two in the Duel of Sorcery series. She has also published several short stories. Clayton began writing only after she was well into her career. We asked her why she decided to become a writer and why she chose science fiction. I've been teaching for a number of years. And I'm also an artist. I draw a lot. And I was much more interested in painting and drawing for my first years than I was in writing. But I gradually came to see that while I have a gift for rendering, I can do quite good individual objects. I don't have any feel for design. And I wasn't willing to take the trouble to get work for that deal. So I decided to remain very much an amateur as a painter. But having drawn that conclusion and being in a situation where I needed to get out, I was about ready to bang my head against the walls. I'm not going to be your examples of teacher burnout. And so I started writing as a way of breaking away from the job I was in. And science fiction, well, because I've always loved it, because I thought I could write it. And it is an awful lot of fun making up worlds. Basically, that's it. Clayton's first novel, published in 1977, was Diadem from the Stars. She's published six more novels in the series since then. The protagonist is Elitist, a strange girl from a backward planet who accidentally acquires the Diadem, an alien artifact which contains the essences and identities of three remarkable humans. We asked Clayton if she had the entire series planned before she wrote the first novel. It's like just about every one of the novels that I write. I know where I'm starting, and I know my characters, and I know my world. In this case, it's a series of worlds. And I know where I'm going, but how I'm going to get there develops. I don't think I could write any other way. I mean, it would be boring if I knew everything before I started. For example, in Star Hunters, one of the secondary leads in that, the woman who was more or less a toy, a plaything, the wife of one of the other secondary leads in the subplot, is only supposed to be in there for about three pages and so. But I suddenly got very interested in her, or she got me interested in her, and she began to take over, and she became a very important part of the book. And this was totally, totally unexpected. During each installment in the Diadem series, Elitist learns more about her past and her quest. Here Clayton tells us of her plans for Elitist in the series. In the beginning, I meant to have Elitist reach her, find her mother and her family in, well, about the same as the number of books. I think there'll be about nine in all. I just finished one and turned it in. I think that's the eighth. And the next one will probably be the last in that particular series, dealing with Elitist as the main character. Each book, I hope, shows, makes Elitist a little bit more aware of who she is and what she really wants rather than what she thought she wanted. And in the end, she's going to end up, I hope, satisfied with where she is working and living in that place for a while anyway. So I knew I was going to have her find her mother and her mother's world. How I was going to get there, depending upon the inspiration and the desperation of the moment. We'll have more on our next show with Joe Clayton. This has been the Science Fiction Radio Show, a production of the Permian Basin Science Fiction Association, produced in conjunction with Odessa College in Odessa, Texas. And in one case, we're all thinking about her home型-ledism. Coming up next is the Science Fiction Radio Show, so stay with us. This is the Science Fiction Radio Show, a commentary on science fiction and fantasy. And here are your hosts. This is Daryl Lane and Bill Vernon. Joe Clayton's Diadem series comprises seven novels so far. These are Diadem from the Stars, Lamarcos, Ursud, Maeve, Star Hunters, The Nowhere Hunt, and Ghost Hunt. Clayton's settings are well done. The action is exciting, and her characters are deep and believable. In fact, the series is carried by the protagonist, Elidus, who is on a quest to uncover her heritage. We were curious how the series got started. Did Clayton conceive of Elidus or the Diadem first? Well, Elidus is the character, first of all. Actually, the first image that hit me was that first page of the first book. I just got this feeling for something suddenly and breaking into the world that she knew. The crash of the ship of the thief. He was also one of the first characters I came up with. I could see him in his flight. Well, I see these things. You know, once I get to know them, I'm a very visual person. There's this little movie screen in the front of my head that goes through. But those are the things that came first of all. The picture of the thief in flight. I didn't know what he had stolen. The crashing on the world. I didn't know what that crash meant. And slowly building up complications. I like complications. When Warren reads the Diadem series sequentially, he sees the continuing evolution of Clayton's writing style. Yes. For instance, the first novel carefully explains the concept of the Diadem, the alien artifact containing three trapped human spirits. It also covers how elitists learn to draw power from it. But in the later novels, the Diadem more or less takes a back seat to other issues. Here Clayton comments. I also am thinking of the series as my workshop education in writing. And the concepts I might have had in the beginning, I'm not going to stick with them. I'll modify them as necessary as I learn more about my craft. More and more, in the last books, I hope, the character of the people who are trapped in the Diadem is coming through. And as they come out, achieve re-embodied, or whatever you want to call it, they become more and more real to me, and more important than the Diadem itself. Elitists is a very tough, strong character. This happened partly because of Clayton's experience in dealing with teenagers as a teacher. She consequently had to place elitists in situations where even her powers would be tested. I said before that I was in a situation where I was really banging my head against the wall. I was teaching English, you know, and while this is very important, there were so many things happening to my kids. I guess I got too involved with them. That I was totally helpless to alleviate things that, you know, the pressures on them, the wounds that they got from the world around them, that I was just absolutely useless in helping them live through. Only I created perhaps a character that was, in the end, a little bit too powerful, too able to go to, well, magic her way out of things. So I had to recreate problems for her and help her come to an understanding of the limitations of power, which I guess is one of the themes in, if there are themes in what I'm writing. More on our next show with Joe Clayton. This has been the Science Fiction Radio Show, a production of the Permian Basin Science Fiction Association, produced in conjunction with Odessa College in Odessa, Texas. This has been the Science Fiction Radio Show, coming up next is the Science Fiction Radio Show, so stay with us. This is the Science Fiction Radio Show, a commentary on science fiction and fantasy. And here are your hosts. This is Bill Vernon. And Daryl Lane. Joe Clayton has written seven science fiction novels in the Diadem series. She has plans for writing two more. But Clayton has also written two novels so far in the Duel of Sorcery series, which is fantasy. These novels are Moongather and Moonscatter. We asked Clayton why she decided to write fantasy amidst writing all that science fiction. Here she tells us about the rather unique source of inspiration. Oh? There's a cockroach sat down beside me one day. That is the literal truth. It's one of these huge ones, about three inches long. I'm sitting, you know, I told you I lived in this little place, little old shotgun apartment above a private house, and I'm sitting on the steps waiting for the mailman to come. It's the thing I do, you know, writers do. And this cockroach came crawling down the side of the house, and it sat there and it looked at me. And, you know, your first reaction with a cockroach is smash it. But I decided just to sit there and look at it, and it's a really disgusting little creature. Actually, it's kind of pretty in its way. Very nice lines, very bright black eyes. We looked alert. And it just sat there, and we looked at each other for a while. And so I decided to write a story about a cockroach, and I decided that it was going to be fantasy. It just seemed to fit in fantasy. So that cockroach ended up, I believe, with about maybe 10 pages out of 300 or something like that. But he was in there. He was my inspiration. And, I don't know, it just felt like a writing fantasy. It wasn't any great and momentous decision. It's just the way it turned out. The Cockroach Passage, by the way, is in the first novel in the series, Moongather. Sometimes fantasy is criticized as being someone easier to write than science fiction because there are no rules to break. Right. Science fiction takes place in a world with consistent logic, whereas in fantasy one can resort to magic when things appear hopeless. If clumsily handled, such antics can irritate the reader. Clayton told us, though, that she believes well-written fantasy follows rules. I am one of those who really believes that there are rules to magic. I don't believe in magic at all, but it's fun to play with. It's, I don't know, it's sort of an extension of the psionics, which is probably, at present, is not a science either. Might be, but many people are skeptical about that. But I can't, it is just the same thing in a sense as writing science fiction, only you write in other terms the same kind of rule keeping. And the societies, you can play with visual things and possibilities in a different way. It's not more loose than science fiction if you do it properly, I think. It just has a different set of assumptions. And it's fun to play with those assumptions. So, fantasy or science fiction? Joe Clayton's carefully crafted work is worth reading. This has been the Science Fiction Radio Show, a production of the Permian Basin Science Fiction Association, produced in conjunction with Odessa College. in Odessa, Texas. Thank you. Coming up next is the Science Fiction Radio Show, so stay with us. This is the Science Fiction Radio Show, a commentary on science fiction and fantasy. And here are your hosts. This is Daryl Lane. And Bill Vernon. Science fiction is a genre which invites writers to use a wide variety of writing styles. One writer who recently emerged with a very distinctive style is Ann Maxwell, whose first novel, Change, was published in 1975. We asked Maxwell how she decided to become a writer. My husband was working overnight as a reporter in Riverside, California. So I decided that I would write with myself, and that's what I did. Maxwell's multi-layered, complex style is best seen in her series of four loosely connected novels, The Singer Enigma, A Dead God Dancing, Name of a Shadow, and Jaws of Minx. Set in the far future, these novels feature a common known universe governed by a body called the Concord. The novels don't share common characters, though. We wondered if Maxwell anticipated writing a series when she began the first novel, The Singer Enigma. I decided that it had been fun to write a book with Earth as a base for a first book. But I was, I truly wanted the freedom that would come from not having the Earth as we know it now in the book. And therefore I had to invent a system. And systems do, you know, people do tend toward hierarchy and governments. And so I thought about those sorts of things for a while until I created a framework within which I could create different cultures that would yet be comprehensible through the larger framework, in this case of Concord. It was a great deal of fun, a great intellectual play to sit there and try to figure out how people who are radically different might find ways to get along. And that in essence was what the Concord was, the soul restraint against undeclared war, that sort of thing. I at that time did not envision writing a series with continuing characters, but I did envision writing more books within that universe. Maxwell treats male-female relationships in great depth, not only in this series, but in her other works, both in science fiction and out. All her novels feature relationships between men and women of strong character. Hear Maxwell comments. Yes, it always has. I think that two strong people, a man and a woman, together can create possibilities that neither alone would have. This is not two weak people holding each other up. This is two strong people using relationships as a springboard to other things. And yes, this is such a deeply held belief on my part that it's sort of like pointing out that there's oxygen in the air to me. Now, I know other people don't see life like that. This is simply one of my beliefs. And it is ineradicable. It appears in all of my books, no matter what they are. This series also features telepathic communications among various characters. An interesting mechanical point is that the telepathic conversations are punctuated with asterisks, rather than with italics or quotation marks, except in the last novel, The Jaws of Menks. We asked Maxwell if this was her publisher's idea. Oh, I wanted to do that. In fact, I did that up until Cigna NIL. And then Jaws of Menks came out, and it was italicized instead of asterisk, which came as a surprise to me, because it was submitted in asterisk. And at that point, there was no way to object. It was a style change made by the house. My contracts and I leave, and I see all such changes before they occur. But at that point, you know, I have stuck with it, because it is the style of the house and the break that's made. But I did resent, in a way, losing the ability to italicize for emphasis, because you can't use that for telepathy and emphasis, at least not very often, and not get away with it without confusing the reader. That's why I chose the asterisk in the first place, to give me greater freedom. We'll have more with Anne Maxwell on our next show. This has been the Science Fiction Radio Show, a production of the Permian Basin Science Fiction Association, produced in conjunction with Odessa College in Odessa, Texas. Thank you. Coming up next is the Science Fiction Radio Show, so stay with us. This is the Science Fiction Radio Show, a commentary on science fiction and fantasy. And here are your hosts. This is Bill Vernon. And Daryl Lane. And Max will begin a new science fiction series with the publication of Fire Dancer in 1982. Dancer's Luck and Dancer's Illusion have come out since then. Unlike Maxwell's other science fiction series, this one consists of tightly connected novels. Maxwell's writing philosophy in the Fire Dancer series is quite different from that she used to write the Concord series. I'm sure you've noticed the break between, say, Jaws of Manx and Fire Dancer. It's the break not only of the universe that it was written in, but of the intent of the books themselves. Fire Dancer. I sat down intending to write a full-on, very accessible romp and enjoyed it thoroughly. And from the response from the readers, I can only say they must have too. Whereas with the earlier books, the Concord books, they are less accessible, far more multilayered, and certainly did not attract the larger audience that the Fire Dancer series has. They're just different books. The Fire Dancer series is built around the relationship between Reba, a Senian dancer, and her Brynn mentor, Kirtan. Reba is a young dancer who literally commands energy. When she dances, the energy streams from her as if it were fire. Kirtan, who is of an alien species, helps Reba learn to control and modulate her powers. Reba and Kirtan are among the last of their respective races, and they are attempting in the series to locate other survivors. Since it's not spelled out in the series, we asked Maxwell to tell us how the relationship between the dancers and the Brynn might have evolved. They are constructs, as Kna is a construct, in that sense. In other words, we are talking about a universe in which the, what we would call human, or whatever you want to call it, is not new. It has evolved independently. It has evolved with self-force evolution. It has evolved in other people's labs against their will. This is a, not a world in which logic, as we understand it, biology, is always going to be followed through. It is simply a universe in which that which could survive and was created, did, and has. And when you come to the darkness between the cycles, then you get a, both a flowering and a weeding out. And what can survive that darkness does in a changed form. In this sense, what we are talking about is the potential for a deep telepathy that became realized to the point that it was necessary. It was a necessary channel for the Brynn and for the dancers who lack, whose gifts come upon them rather all at once, and lack the ability to control them at first. Then you, you become a situation where you are a symbiont, but not in the normal physical sense. They can live separately. You can feed them separately. Generally, they will lose themselves. They, to be, to reach anything approaching their fullest potential, they must be paired. However, not all Brynn's and not all Zinyasi are dancers, and the ones who aren't, are the basic changes that they need to rest at all. There are many unanswered questions remaining after three installments of the Fire Dancer series. We asked Maxwell if she plans to wrap it up soon. Well, I must say that I would never, in one sense, totally resolve the dancer thing. In other words, even if they do achieve some of Ravis' goals, that is a beginning as well as an ending. If you have a whole new planet of dancers plus the residue of slaves and talents from the planet Lu, you are going to have a world, once again, that is dynamic, that is a synthesis of the past rather than the repetition of it. And Maxwell has presented science fiction with two very interesting yet quite different series. She certainly arrived to watch. This has been the Science Fiction Radio Show, a production of the Permian Basin Science Fiction Association, produced in conjunction with Odessa College in Odessa, Texas. The Science Fiction Radio Show, a production of the Permian Basin Science Fiction Association,

segments.text: Coming up next is the Science Fiction Radio Show, so stay with us.
This is the Science Fiction Radio Show, a commentary on science fiction and fantasy.
And here are your hosts.
This is Bill Vernon and Daryl Lane.
Jo Clayton is a science fiction and fantasy writer who is a discovery of Donald A. Walheim, publisher of Dahl Books.
Other recent Walheim discoveries are C.J. Sherry and Tanith Lee.
Clayton has published seven novels in the Diadem series and two in the Duel of Sorcery series.
She has also published several short stories.
Clayton began writing only after she was well into her career.
We asked her why she decided to become a writer and why she chose science fiction.
I've been teaching for a number of years.
And I'm also an artist.
I draw a lot.
And I was much more interested in painting and drawing for my first years than I was in writing.
But I gradually came to see that while I have a gift for rendering, I can do quite good individual objects.
I don't have any feel for design.
And I wasn't willing to take the trouble to get work for that deal.
So I decided to remain very much an amateur as a painter.
But having drawn that conclusion and being in a situation where I needed to get out, I was about ready to bang my head against the walls.
I'm not going to be your examples of teacher burnout.
And so I started writing as a way of breaking away from the job I was in.
And science fiction, well, because I've always loved it, because I thought I could write it.
And it is an awful lot of fun making up worlds.
Basically, that's it.
Clayton's first novel, published in 1977, was Diadem from the Stars.
She's published six more novels in the series since then.
The protagonist is Elitist, a strange girl from a backward planet who accidentally acquires the Diadem,
an alien artifact which contains the essences and identities of three remarkable humans.
We asked Clayton if she had the entire series planned before she wrote the first novel.
It's like just about every one of the novels that I write.
I know where I'm starting, and I know my characters, and I know my world.
In this case, it's a series of worlds.
And I know where I'm going, but how I'm going to get there develops.
I don't think I could write any other way.
I mean, it would be boring if I knew everything before I started.
For example, in Star Hunters, one of the secondary leads in that,
the woman who was more or less a toy, a plaything,
the wife of one of the other secondary leads in the subplot,
is only supposed to be in there for about three pages and so.
But I suddenly got very interested in her, or she got me interested in her,
and she began to take over, and she became a very important part of the book.
And this was totally, totally unexpected.
During each installment in the Diadem series,
Elitist learns more about her past and her quest.
Here Clayton tells us of her plans for Elitist in the series.
In the beginning, I meant to have Elitist reach her,
find her mother and her family in, well, about the same as the number of books.
I think there'll be about nine in all.
I just finished one and turned it in.
I think that's the eighth.
And the next one will probably be the last in that particular series,
dealing with Elitist as the main character.
Each book, I hope, shows, makes Elitist a little bit more aware of who she is
and what she really wants rather than what she thought she wanted.
And in the end, she's going to end up, I hope,
satisfied with where she is working and living in that place for a while anyway.
So I knew I was going to have her find her mother and her mother's world.
How I was going to get there,
depending upon the inspiration and the desperation of the moment.
We'll have more on our next show with Joe Clayton.
This has been the Science Fiction Radio Show,
a production of the Permian Basin Science Fiction Association,
produced in conjunction with Odessa College in Odessa, Texas.

Oh?
There's a cockroach sat down beside me one day.
That is the literal truth.
It's one of these huge ones, about three inches long.
I'm sitting, you know, I told you I lived in this little place,
little old shotgun apartment above a private house,

And so I decided to write a story about a cockroach,
and I decided that it was going to be fantasy.

So that cockroach ended up, I believe,
with about maybe 10 pages out of 300 or something like that.
But he was in there.
He was my inspiration.
And, I don't know, it just felt like a writing fantasy.

It's just the way it turned out.
The Cockroach Passage, by the way, is in the first novel in the series, Moongather.
Sometimes fantasy is criticized as being someone easier to write than science fiction
because there are no rules to break.
Right.

whereas in fantasy one can resort to magic when things appear hopeless.

I am one of those who really believes that there are rules to magic.

which is probably, at present, is not a science either.

only you write in other terms the same kind of rule keeping.
And the societies, you can play with visual things and possibilities in a different way.
It's not more loose than science fiction if you do it properly, I think.
It just has a different set of assumptions.
And it's fun to play with those assumptions.

Joe Clayton's carefully crafted work is worth reading.

Coming up next is the Science Fiction Radio Show, so stay with us.
This is the Science Fiction Radio Show,
a commentary on science fiction and fantasy.
And here are your hosts.
This is Daryl Lane.
And Bill Vernon.
Science fiction is a genre which invites writers to use a wide variety of writing styles.
One writer who recently emerged with a very distinctive style is Ann Maxwell,
whose first novel, Change, was published in 1975.
We asked Maxwell how she decided to become a writer.
My husband was working overnight as a reporter in Riverside, California.
So I decided that I would write with myself, and that's what I did.
Maxwell's multi-layered, complex style is best seen in her series of four loosely connected novels,
The Singer Enigma, A Dead God Dancing, Name of a Shadow, and Jaws of Minx.
Set in the far future, these novels feature a common known universe governed by a body called the Concord.
The novels don't share common characters, though.
We wondered if Maxwell anticipated writing a series when she began the first novel, The Singer Enigma.
I decided that it had been fun to write a book with Earth as a base for a first book.
But I was, I truly wanted the freedom that would come from not having the Earth as we know it now in the book.
And therefore I had to invent a system.
And systems do, you know, people do tend toward hierarchy and governments.
And so I thought about those sorts of things for a while until I created a framework within which I could create different cultures
that would yet be comprehensible through the larger framework, in this case of Concord.
It was a great deal of fun, a great intellectual play to sit there and try to figure out how people who are radically different might find ways to get along.
And that in essence was what the Concord was, the soul restraint against undeclared war, that sort of thing.
I at that time did not envision writing a series with continuing characters, but I did envision writing more books within that universe.
Maxwell treats male-female relationships in great depth, not only in this series, but in her other works, both in science fiction and out.
All her novels feature relationships between men and women of strong character.
Hear Maxwell comments.
Yes, it always has.
I think that two strong people, a man and a woman, together can create possibilities that neither alone would have.
This is not two weak people holding each other up.
This is two strong people using relationships as a springboard to other things.
And yes, this is such a deeply held belief on my part that it's sort of like pointing out that there's oxygen in the air to me.
Now, I know other people don't see life like that.
This is simply one of my beliefs.
And it is ineradicable.
It appears in all of my books, no matter what they are.
This series also features telepathic communications among various characters.
An interesting mechanical point is that the telepathic conversations are punctuated with asterisks, rather than with italics or quotation marks, except in the last novel, The Jaws of Menks.
We asked Maxwell if this was her publisher's idea.
Oh, I wanted to do that.
In fact, I did that up until Cigna NIL.
And then Jaws of Menks came out, and it was italicized instead of asterisk, which came as a surprise to me, because it was submitted in asterisk.
And at that point, there was no way to object.
It was a style change made by the house.
My contracts and I leave, and I see all such changes before they occur.
But at that point, you know, I have stuck with it, because it is the style of the house and the break that's made.

But I did resent, in a way, losing the ability to italicize for emphasis, because you can't use that for telepathy and emphasis, at least not very often, and not get away with it without confusing the reader.
That's why I chose the asterisk in the first place, to give me greater freedom.

And Max will begin a new science fiction series with the publication of Fire Dancer in 1982.
Dancer's Luck and Dancer's Illusion have come out since then.
Unlike Maxwell's other science fiction series, this one consists of tightly connected novels.
Maxwell's writing philosophy in the Fire Dancer series is quite different from that she used to write the Concord series.
I'm sure you've noticed the break between, say, Jaws of Manx and Fire Dancer.
It's the break not only of the universe that it was written in, but of the intent of the books themselves.
Fire Dancer.
I sat down intending to write a full-on, very accessible romp and enjoyed it thoroughly.
And from the response from the readers, I can only say they must have too.
Whereas with the earlier books, the Concord books, they are less accessible, far more multilayered, and certainly did not attract the larger audience that the Fire Dancer series has.
They're just different books.
The Fire Dancer series is built around the relationship between Reba, a Senian dancer, and her Brynn mentor, Kirtan.
Reba is a young dancer who literally commands energy.
When she dances, the energy streams from her as if it were fire.
Kirtan, who is of an alien species, helps Reba learn to control and modulate her powers.
Reba and Kirtan are among the last of their respective races, and they are attempting in the series to locate other survivors.
Since it's not spelled out in the series, we asked Maxwell to tell us how the relationship between the dancers and the Brynn might have evolved.
They are constructs, as Kna is a construct, in that sense.
In other words, we are talking about a universe in which the, what we would call human, or whatever you want to call it, is not new.
It has evolved independently.
It has evolved with self-force evolution.
It has evolved in other people's labs against their will.
This is a, not a world in which logic, as we understand it, biology, is always going to be followed through.
It is simply a universe in which that which could survive and was created, did, and has.
And when you come to the darkness between the cycles, then you get a, both a flowering and a weeding out.
And what can survive that darkness does in a changed form.
In this sense, what we are talking about is the potential for a deep telepathy that became realized to the point that it was necessary.
It was a necessary channel for the Brynn and for the dancers who lack, whose gifts come upon them rather all at once, and lack the ability to control them at first.
Then you, you become a situation where you are a symbiont, but not in the normal physical sense.
They can live separately. You can feed them separately.
Generally, they will lose themselves.
They, to be, to reach anything approaching their fullest potential, they must be paired.
However, not all Brynn's and not all Zinyasi are dancers, and the ones who aren't, are the basic changes that they need to rest at all.
There are many unanswered questions remaining after three installments of the Fire Dancer series.
We asked Maxwell if she plans to wrap it up soon.
Well, I must say that I would never, in one sense, totally resolve the dancer thing.
In other words, even if they do achieve some of Ravis' goals, that is a beginning as well as an ending.
If you have a whole new planet of dancers plus the residue of slaves and talents from the planet Lu,
you are going to have a world, once again, that is dynamic, that is a synthesis of the past rather than the repetition of it.
And Maxwell has presented science fiction with two very interesting yet quite different series.
She certainly arrived to watch.
